6DCAEDF25F8541FA9635FAD0F90958E5.description: Discuss first-aid procedures for exposure to agricultural chemicals (e.g., fertilizer, pesticide, fuel and anhydrous ammonia).

2DD93F9EC8FF43DBB7F30E6F2ABDAEB7.description: Develop procedures for handling mishaps such as chemical spills.

8E0F4495BED346AABBE6C5CFE1FE30B9.description: Practise the safe storage of chemical products.

41D8556421944BE6BAC7B068355C40D9.description: Demonstrate safe handling of chemical products using approved safety gear.

712963D319AA48CB8207161FC801C4A5.description: Explain the uses of agricultural chemicals that would require a Saskatchewan Pesticide Applicator Licence.

F7EDAF94D7E041E095483AABF3C445F4.description: Explore training and certification opportunities (e.g., WHMIS and pesticide applicator licence) on the safe use of agricultural chemicals.

F2C63C8741294D998A71D0C8F0E37056.description: Investigate record keeping strategies for maintaining SDS information.

B3A4688E75234172A9ACF304EFBF7ED2.description: Describe the potential heath risks of exposure to chemicals.

3B896D97472141A59CB208C9FBA232EC.description: Identify the types of hazardous materials that an agricultural operation might create.

61FDA9676AE14F6EA07AD6D49E134E73.description: Discuss the purpose and intended use of the mandatory information on a pesticide label as regulated by Health Canada.

11BCA1CE26EB4F199A8A4934DEAF8F0A.description: Demonstrate the different hazards, identifiers and uses of consumer products, control products, and pesticides.

C8222090005949529BA02EBB3DC91276.description: Describe the four parts of Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS) (i.e., labels with warning symbols, hazard identification and product classification, Safety Data Sheets (SDS), worker education and worksite specific training).

326EBEB5D3A9450A987847C4CC3EA28B.description: Identify important information categories from product labels, Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) and manufacturer’s chemical information packages such as compatibility, storage requirements, application method, preharvest intervals and withdrawal periods.

0D1FEC52182749AD9C4466C37F3C4880.description: Demonstrate the importance of, and methods used for, maintenance of a clean and safe workplace.

80BE8A7F70B14BE080B0C1A3D1660553.description: Apply proper handling of hazardous materials to prevent injury in the workplace.

C8A66A472CC5474CAC039ABB7C1548C4.description: Investigate the impact of major events offered in Saskatchewan that promote agriculture.

252990219A8A4AAABC0A209CC1AA0ACD.description: Identify current events, trends and issues (e.g., population growth and climate change) affecting the agriculture industry in Saskatchewan

B11752494EA047CDA91ECEA63A7EF776.description: Explore how agriculture, carbon sequestration, and sustainable agriculture practices can be part of nature-based climate solutions.

634BB1D40F524502B6AC3E7590800B50.description: Explore Saskatchewan’s agricultural value regarding growing, processing and exporting food for provincial, national and global markets.

580E0EFC666448229FC9DB7058A622F6.description: Describe related services that support agriculture production (e.g., research, storage and transportation).

30A9D8FDD1C3468DAB27024D694BDE6E.description: Apply terms commonly associated with the agriculture industry in Saskatchewan

24D42B1795DD457D855E33E3074416E5.description: Research terms commonly associated with the agriculture industry in Saskatchewan, including: biosecurity; commodities; consumers; diversified agriculture; livestock; markets; mixed farming; plant protein; primary production; producers; product; production agriculture; secondary industry; and, value-added agriculture.

993B742E9E6F47269765EC8A06500515.description: Examine agriculture’s connections to Saskatchewan’s economy

D9A7C48CF2CC4296878955A2B9D5A2C5.description: Investigate the impact and significance of agriculture in Saskatchewan.
